transcripts.text: So I think the answer is you're not able to come up with the amount of the payments or the amount financed.
I am telling you that there are a lot of things.

Sounds like that's a no.  So I brought the teacher's manual and I just want to read to you.  This is a straightforward problem that simply tests whether the students mastered the basics.  The amount financed is calculated by subtracting.  The finance charge from the total of payments, 7,604.30 minus 1,496.80.  That's it.  The amount of the payments, you take the total of the payments, 7,604.3, and you divide by 36.  It's $211.
And the hectoring of the witness about math problems is quite insulting to all of us on this committee.
To the contrary, Mr.  McHenry.  Math problems are exactly what... the Bureau's Your Money, Your Goals educational program is about, in which the semiannual report of the director says...

I would not yield.  Your Money, Your Goals program is designed to use to build your own financial skills and confidence and to be able to start money conversations with the people that they serve.  So I'm asking Ms.  Kraninger about her own skills and confidence so that she can administer the program that she is touting in this semiannual report.

Well, I would say as point of fact, I don't necessarily get in the weeds of administering that program.  There are 1,500 people at the agency.  Fabulous.  They do certainly have many people out in the field.

Reclaiming my time, I appreciate that staff do much of the work, but staff, consumers in the marketplace do not have staff to understand these disclosures.  They're out there by themselves.  trying to figure it out.  You, in fact, are in charge of making sure that the lenders, often entry-level rank and file employees, fill these disclosures out correctly.  So as the head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, when you see these disclosures, you have to be able to know if they are correctly completed or incorrectly completed.  Otherwise, you can't do the enforcement work.
